comment.author: 48207431@N00
comment._content: I have found a 'possible' in The Times, one William Hall. I will provide a transcription here and apologise for the size of my comment. I write from Australia and wonder if someone more local might be able to follow up the clues in the article to see if this is 'our man'. Transcription: [The Times (London, England), Tuesday, Aug 30, 1932; pg. 12; Issue 46225.]. Man Killed By Fall From A Roof: Slip When Defying Police William Hall, lately living at Newcastle-on-Tyne, was killed by a fall from the roof of a house at Newcastle early yesterday. It was stated that the police were about to arrest him and another man for alleged attempted burglary at a near-by hotel. The other man was arrested. At Newcastle police court yesterday, JAMES BISCOFF WHITEHEAD, 28, of Back Scotswood Road, unemployed, labourer, was remanded for a week on a charge of attempting to break into Benwell Hotel in Adelaide Terrace with intent to commit a felony. Inspector Russell said he surrounded the building with the aid of persons living near by. Hall, the dead man, who had a jemmy, knocked off a chimney stack and threw slates and masonry on to the crowd below. In attempting to knock off another chimney pot he fell into the backyard and met his death through a fractured skull. The witness added that Whitehead jumped into the back lane and was arrested. [Many thanks to Tyne and Wear Archives and Museums for uploading these extraordinary photographs, and to the State Library of Western Australia for their research seminars and online resources].

comment._content: Congratulations to Wattlesong for that detective work which adds a fascinating postscript to this particularly interesting mugshot. And indeed congratulation to TWAS for making this incredible series of images available online.

comment.author: 62626798@N04
comment._content: Fascinating photos - reminiscent of Hugh Welch Diamond's earlier photos of 'lunatics' - many of whom just happened to be destitute and desperate.

comment.author: 39821974@N06
comment._content:
Using the date provided by Wattlesong we found an article in the Evening Chronicle for the 29th of August 1932. The incident which occurred in the early hours of that morning made front page news.

The article states that the dead man was Robert William Hall (54) and was lodging in Brunel Terrace. His aliases are listed as William Jones and Robert Dodds. The Fire Brigade had come out to assist in the incident and local residents were praised by the police for their valuable assistance.

Highlights of Robert William Hall’s career are described including non attendance at school and his serving an eleven year sentence in Sing Sing for a street shooting in Chicago. In an earlier incident he had threatened police with a razor during a break in at the Forth Hotel.

He was well known as a street musician and it is alleged that he even played his violin in city mission halls where his character was not known.

Interestingly the photograph of Hall that is used in the article is the same one that is shown here.

comment.author: 43805217@N00
comment._content: This case is intriguing- i am of the opinion of Seth above, I think the last two digits on the cards are the year the felon was photographed (numbers at top right just below the photograph). More interesting is Mr Hall's shooting conviction in the USA - I'm assuming he was a Geordie although what if he was indeed an American? If a native of Newcastle, why did he go to the USA? There is an interesting story to be told here....
